Realizing the ProblemReturning to grad school after a break, I quickly realized how much my ability to focus had deteriorated. I used to work for hours without distractions, but now, constant digital interruptions and *doom-scrolling* had eroded my concentration.It became difficult to even sit through a 20-minute video, let alone focus on tasks. Despite attempts like caffeine, quiet spaces, and packed schedules, nothing seemed to help. In Gen Z terms, I had fallen victim to social media brain rot. ğŸ§ ğŸ“±

After a deep dive into *YouTube* and *Google*, I found countless people sharing similar struggles, alongside potential solutions. ğŸš¨How Iâ€™m Fixing It ğŸ› ï¸### 1. Embrace the Boredom ğŸ«¥Itâ€™s time to **get comfy with being bored**. The moment you reach for your phone is when youâ€™re actually *bored*. Try doing stuff without distractionsâ€”like eating without scrolling through your phone or showering without music. It's annoying at first, but trust me, it works.2. Be Intentional with What You Watch ğŸ¥I love watching videos while I eat. But instead of mindlessly watching shorts or quick YouTube clips, I now force myself to watch something longer and more meaningful. Itâ€™s like training your brain to focus again.
3. The Pomodoro Technique â²ï¸When I need to grind through work, I use the Pomodoro Technique. Itâ€™s all about working in focused bursts with timed breaks in between. If you havenâ€™t tried it, you can learn more about it here.
Here are a couple of timers Iâ€™ve been using:
Aesthetic Pomodoro TimerPomodoro Chrome Extension4. Detox from Social Media ğŸš«This one is hard, but cutting down on social media is essential. You donâ€™t have to do it all at once. Just start by spending more time hanging out with friends, joining clubs, or studying with people. Youâ€™ll feel tired, but also clear-minded.
5. Study with Strangers ğŸ‘¥If you need a little extra push, there are these study-with-strangers online groups where you can study alongside others in real time:
Study TogetherStudyStream6. Adventure Studying ğŸŒSometimes a change of scenery can help. I call it adventure studyingâ€”whether itâ€™s a cafÃ©, a park, or somewhere youâ€™ve never studied before. For me, IHOP has become a favorite spot. Try finding a place you like and shake up your routine.
Disclaimer: I'm not sponsored by or affiliated with any of the websites, apps, or tools I mentioned. Be sure to do your own research before using any of them to make sure they suit your needs.ConclusionRemember, **it's not a sprint; it's a marathon**. Recovery takes time, but the more you practice being mindful, the stronger your focus will get. Whether you're just starting or already deep into the process, progress is progress. ğŸ’ª

content:
The Hackathon Kickoff!
Participating in my first-ever hackathon was a wild ride. As someone new to the hackathon scene, I didnâ€™t really know what to expect. But with some determination, teamwork, and a little bit of luck, my team and I managed not just to participateâ€”but actually win!
The Journey BeginsIt was around 6 PM when I got a message saying it was going to snow that night. I quickly packed up my hoodie, grabbed my favorite keyboard, and headed out with my friend. Just like me, my teammates hadn’t done a hackathon before either, and none of us came from a computer science background, so we were already at a bit of a disadvantage.
When I got into the car, my friend casually mentioned, â€œLetâ€™s just have a good time.â€ I couldnâ€™t help but respond, â€œWell, if Iâ€™m doing this, Iâ€™m aiming to win.â€ It was one of those moments where you say something without fully knowing how it will turn out. He just laughed, not taking it too seriously.
Forming the TeamWhen the hackathon kicked off, while the other teams were diving into their projects, we were still trying to figure out what to build. But we had one advantage: we were all grad students. I had some app development experience, so I suggested we use Flutter. The first few hours were spent watching tutorials just to get it installed. My friend and I also procrastinated a bitâ€”we still had homework to doâ€”so it wasnâ€™t an easy start. Itâ€™s funny looking back now, but there was definitely some tension in the air.
Building the Project: Echoes of EqualityWith my background in app development, I took charge of setting up the architecture and showing everyone what was possible with Flutter. As we started implementing features, we all began to feel a bit more confident.
The Night StrugglesAs the night went on, we hit a snag. We needed to use Firebase, which is usually a breeze for me, but that night, it just wasnâ€™t working. I wasted hours on it and couldnâ€™t get it to work. Just when I was about to take a nap out of frustration, my friend managed to pull it off. It was a huge relief. But then, of course, we got greedy and decided to add more and more features.
The Final PushI could go on and on about the rest of the hackathon, but the bottom line is, we werenâ€™t sure how it would turn out until the very end. But when we presented our app, everyone loved it. They were so impressed, they said they wanted to use it in their daily lives right away. In the end, we won both the Beginner Category and the LGBTQIA+ Category.
ReflectionsItâ€™s a bit of a drag that we couldnâ€™t take the app any further, but we received a lot of appreciation from all over the CS department, including the Head of the Department. The organizer even mentioned us in a LinkedIn post! You can check it out here.
If youâ€™re curious to learn more about “Echoes of Equality,” you can check out the project on DevPost.
GalleryHere’s a collection of images that capture the spirit of the hackathon:
I hope this gives you a good sense of what itâ€™s like to participate in a hackathon. Whether youâ€™re a seasoned coder or a newbie like I was, thereâ€™s something incredibly rewarding about pushing your limits and seeing what you can achieve.
title: My First Ever Hackathon Experience: Spoiler Alert - I Won!

Moving from Golden Rock in India to Golden, Colorado, has been a journey filled with cultural contrasts and unexpected surprises...Tap Water: The First Scary SipBack home in India, tap water is something you wouldn’t dream of drinking without boiling or filtering first. But here in the US, everyone drinks straight from the tap! At first, I hesitated and stared at the glass, wondering if this was a good idea. But soon, I got used to it, and now, I love the convenience (though I still miss our boiled water).
The Mysterious Toilet Seat CoverIn India, we flush and typically use a handheld hose (or bidet) to clean upâ€”it’s quick and thorough. But here in the US, I was introduced to a completely different approach: toilet paper, wipes, and the mysterious toilet seat covers. At first, it was a bit of a puzzle to figure out how to use these covers, but once you get the hang of it, itâ€™s a pretty neat way to keep things clean. If youâ€™re as confused as I was, check out this video on how to set one up:
Also, public restrooms are super clean here, which I absolutely love.
Tipping and Taxes: Surprise at the RegisterOne of the biggest shocks was at the cash registerâ€”why is the price higher than whatâ€™s on the tag? Welcome to the world of taxes that arenâ€™t included in the price, and donâ€™t forget to tip! It took a while to get used to tipping 15-20% on everything, but itâ€™s just part of the culture here.
Honking: Itâ€™s Not What You ThinkIn India, honking is like saying, “Hey, I’m here!” In the US, honking is more like, “What are you doing?!” Itâ€™s less about signaling and more about expressing displeasure, which I quickly learned to avoid.
The Gym: Pounds and Public NudityAs someone who hits the gym regularly, I quickly realized that everything here is in pounds (lbs), not kilograms. To make life easier, I created an app that helps with these conversionsâ€”check it out if youâ€™re in the same boat:
Converter4MeOh, and don’t be surprised if people walk around naked in the locker rooms. It’s totally normal here. Just smile and carry on.
Drinking: Cheers!Drinking is a pretty normal and socially accepted activity here. Whether itâ€™s a casual drink after work or a weekend hangout, alcohol is a common sight.
Holding Doors: The Unexpected CourtesyOne of the most charming aspects of American culture is the way people hold doors open for others. Itâ€™s such a small gesture, but it really makes your day. Iâ€™ve started doing it myself, and itâ€™s a habit Iâ€™m happy to pick up.
Navigating these cultural differences has been both amusing and enlightening. Moving to a new country comes with its challenges, but itâ€™s these little quirks that make the journey worthwhile. If youâ€™re an international student or just curious about these cultural contrasts, I hope you enjoyed this peek into my experience!
summary: Moving from Golden Rock in India to Golden, Colorado, has been a journey filled with cultural contrasts and unexpected surprises.
title: The Culture Shock: From Golden Rock, India to Golden, CO, US

content: I recently came across an analogy that resonated deeply with me, so I wanted to share it. The analogy shows how the same object (or person) can be valued differently depending on the surroundings.Here's the story: A bottle of water at Costco costs $0.25. The same bottle in a supermarket is worth about $0.50. At a bar, the same bottle costs $2. In a high-end restaurant or hotel, the bottle might be priced as high as $3. At an airport or on a plane, the bottle is sold for $5. The bottle and its contents donâ€™t changeâ€”the only thing that varies is where it is being sold. Each environment assigns a different value to the same product.This analogy reminds us that when you feel underappreciated, itâ€™s often not because of who you are, but because of where you are.The Courage to Change PlacesWhen the environment you're in doesn't recognize your worth, itâ€™s important to have the courage to change. Like the bottle, your value remains the same, but it's how others perceive and treat you that changes depending on the environment. Surround yourself with people and places that appreciate your true worth and potential. Donâ€™t settle for less than what you deserve.Takeaway: You are valuable as you are, but not every place will see that. Find the environment that values you, and never settle for less.
summary: I recently came across an analogy that resonated deeply with me, so I wanted to share it.
title: Know Your Worth: The Value of Changing Your Environment
